title: I am a single dad looking for someone to date
self_text: I'm a single dad looking for someone to date, with my daughter who is in middle school. She is very independent and doesn't need a lot of attention so if you are ok with that then we can get along well.  I work as a software engineer. I enjoy reading, hiking, cooking, travelling, watching movies, and going to concerts. I like people who are funny, kind, intelligent, and adventurous.   I have a dog and he would love to meet his new best friend!  You should be able to handle the occasional drama and know how to cook! If that doesn't bother you then let me know!  I'm not looking for a fling or something serious at first so let's start there.  Don't message me if you are an incel, don't want kids or are only interested in casual sex.   I'm also okay with people from other countries, but English must be your first language.  I look forward to hearing from you!

title: The truth about "The Handmaids Tale"
self_text: I think the reason why the story is so popular is because it's not just a simple dystopia and instead, it's more of a psychological thriller where you have to question the morality of those in power and if they are really evil or if they truly believe what they are doing for the greater good. Like the Handmaidens who want to create children by any means necessary, but also want to be seen as pure women.  I feel like that makes them more relatable than other dystopian stories which tend to only show how bad things can get when society goes wrong. Do you agree?

title: How to make a good poached egg
self_text:
For perfect poached eggs, you need to have everything ready before the water boils.   Hereâ€™s how I do it:
1.  Fill your saucepan with about 3 inches of water and bring to a simmerâ€”not a rolling boil! Adding a splash of white wine is optional but can help tenderize the eggs.
2.  Crack your eggs into small ramekins or cups (this makes them easier to lower into the water).
3.  Gently lower each egg into the simmering water, one at a time.
4.  Cook for 3-4 minutes for a runny yolk. Adjust cooking time based on preference.
5.  Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.  Season with salt and pepper. Enjoy!
    (Photos included)

title: I'm a single dad to a son named Liam, and he has a special interest in science.
self_text: So, my Liam loves learning about plants, particularly how they grow. He also loves reading books on genetics and plant breeding.   Recently, we have been talking about the concept of "polyploidy", or multiple sets of chromosomes, as it relates to certain plants like wheat.  He asked me if a plant could just grow another set of chromosomes randomly, and I explained that it doesnâ€™t happen like that. It requires some specific environmental triggers to cause the cells to divide into multiple sets, such as exposure to chemicals.  But then he asked if any of those chemical exposures would allow him to be able to grow an extra chromosome!  I said no, but he did ask if I knew of any scientific experiments that had ever involved that sort of thing.  Then he came back with something that really shocked me: â€œDad, I read about scientists creating a new species of plant called â€œwheatâ€ by exposing normal wheat seeds to chemicals, and turning them into polyploid wheat.â€  I looked up the research on that wheat type and discovered that it was actually created by researchers at Oregon State University in 2017!  The new wheat is called â€œWheatPlusâ€.   When I told him that, he got so excited.  â€œWow, Dad, you can make more wheat with chemicals!â€   Now he wants to become a scientist and study what causes plants to become polyploid.  It is amazing to watch him learn, and even more amazing that he knows about his interest in science.   I am grateful for all the knowledge he brings to our family.  His favorite part is watching videos on YouTube about wheat genetics and plant breeding.  Itâ€™s incredible.

title: I canâ€™t believe it
self_text: A bush is a plant that has a trunk but no branches. A plant that has a trunk and branches is called a tree.  A plant with a trunk, branches, and flowers is called a rose bush.  A plant with a trunk, branches, flowers, and fruit is called a fruit bush.

title: "When I heard the news that my son had cancer, I felt like I had been struck by lightning"
self_text: I thought of how my son was always trying to become a lawyer, but now he's in the hospital fighting for his life. I told him, "Son, you don't need to be a lawyer! You are already a hero!"  It was the first time since hearing the diagnosis that Iâ€™d managed to smile.   My son smiled back. â€œDadâ€ he said, â€œyouâ€™re so sweet.â€   â€œYou can tell your doctorâ€ I said.   He chuckled.  Then he took my hand and said, â€œDad, I love you very much.â€   I wept uncontrollably.   â€œI love you too, son,â€ I choked out.   As I held his hand, a nurse came in and said, â€œMr. Miller, we have good news. The doctors found some antibodies in your sonâ€™s blood that are attacking the cancer cells.â€   I looked at my son, then at the nurse, then back at my son.   â€œWhat do they want to do?â€ I asked.   The nurse replied, â€œWeâ€™re going to give him a high dose of chemotherapy. Itâ€™ll kill the cancer cells, but it will also cause severe side effects. But we believe it is our best chance to save his life.â€   I looked at my son, who squeezed my hand.  â€œDo it!â€ I shouted.   â€œDo it!â€ I repeated.   â€œYes, Dad,â€ my son whispered.   I held his hand tightly as the nurse administered the drug.   After the injection, my son started convulsing. His face turned purple. He gasped for air.   I screamed, â€œWhatâ€™s happening?â€   The nurse replied, â€œHis body is rejecting the medication. We are giving him medicine to stop the convulsions and stabilize him.â€   After a few minutes, my son calmed down.  â€œDad,â€ he said, â€œI feel really bad.â€   â€œDonâ€™t worry, son,â€ I said. â€œYouâ€™ll be okay.â€   â€œDad,â€ he said again, â€œIâ€™ve got something to tell you.â€   â€œWhat is it?â€ I asked.   â€œI just realizedâ€¦ I donâ€™t want to be a lawyer anymore.â€   I stared at my son in disbelief.   â€œWhat?â€ I said.   â€œIâ€™ve decided I want to be a firefighter,â€ he said.   I grabbed my son and hugged him tight.   â€œThatâ€™s wonderful, son!â€ I exclaimed.   â€œHow could you not know?â€ he asked.   â€œI didnâ€™t realize,â€ I said.   â€œWell, now you do,â€ he said.   â€œNow, let's go get some ice cream.â€ I said.   â€œLet's go!â€ he said.  We went outside and into the yard. A woman ran up to us and screamed, â€œMr. Miller! My husband is choking!â€   I grabbed my son, pointed to her and said, â€œGo! Go! Be a firefighter!â€   My son ran toward the fire station.   I followed him and began to perform CPR on the man.   The paramedics arrived and took over.   They brought the man back to life.   After the ambulance left, I sat down and cried.   My son came running back to me.   â€œDad,â€ he said, â€œtheyâ€™re asking for me.â€   â€œGet in there!â€ I yelled.   â€œOkay, Dad,â€ he said.   â€œCome here,â€ I said.   I pulled my son into a hug and said, â€œYou did a great job today.â€   â€œThanks, Dad,â€ he said.   â€œWhatâ€™s wrong with you? Youâ€™re crying,â€ I said.   â€œIâ€™m proud of myself,â€ he said.   â€œI am too,â€ I said.   â€œIâ€™m glad youâ€™re a firefighter,â€ I said.   â€œMe too,â€ he said.   â€œI love you,â€ I said.   â€œI love you too,â€ he said.   â€œYou made me so proud,â€ I said.   â€œThank you, Dad,â€ he said.   â€œYou were amazing,â€ I said.   â€œYou saved his life,â€ I said.   â€œI just wanted to help,â€ he said.   â€œYou did more than help,â€ I said.   â€œYou were a hero,â€ I said.   â€œI just wanted to be a hero,â€ he said.   â€œYou were a hero,â€ I said.   â€œIâ€™m proud of you,â€ I said.   â€œI love you,â€ he said.   â€œI love you too,â€ I said.   â€œThank you, Dad,â€ he said.   â€œYouâ€™re welcome, son,â€ I said.   â€œIâ€™m glad I could help,â€ he said.   â€œYou were great,â€ I said.   â€œIâ€™m glad title: "I'm gonna have a blood clot"

title: I'm a single dad, and my daughter is in elementary school.  I want to buy her some new clothes for the fall season, but don't want her thinking I can't afford anything else.   Do you have any ideas on what I could do?
self_text:
Here are some suggestions:

*   Ask if she has any specific things she wants or needs. This takes the pressure off of you and gives her agency over what she gets. It also helps you avoid buying something she wonâ€™t actually wear.
*   If she doesnâ€™t know exactly what she wants, suggest some items that fit into a certain category (e.g., â€œWould you like a new sweater?â€). Then let her choose from a selection.
*   Buy her clothes on sale or at thrift stores. You can find great deals without breaking the bank.
*   Start a clothing swap with other parents. Everyone brings their outgrown clothes, and then you all trade them.
*   Give her an allowance and let her use it to buy herself clothes.  This teaches financial responsibility.
*   Tell her that you love her very much and that your love for her doesnâ€™t depend on how much money you spend on her.  Thatâ€™s probably the most important thing!
*   If you are having trouble affording something, talk to her about it honestly and simply. Explain that you are doing your best and appreciate what she already has.

Edit: Also, consider asking if she would be okay with wearing hand-me-downs from older siblings or cousins.

title: What does a woman want to be when she's older?
self_text: A ruling matriarch!
